countries.name: Albania
countries.title: Albania Country Guide
countries.description: Leveraging the Adriatic's emerging tech hub and highly competitive operational landscape.

sections.title: Albania Introduction
content: Albania is rapidly transforming into a strategic gateway between the Mediterranean and the rest of Europe. With a focus on digital innovation and a business-friendly environment, it has become an attractive destination for companies seeking high-quality BPO, IT, and administrative support at a competitive cost.

sections.title: What to Know about Albania's Geography
content: Located in Southern Europe on the Balkan Peninsula, Albania boasts extensive coastlines along the Adriatic and Ionian Seas. It shares borders with Montenegro, Kosovo, North Macedonia, and Greece. Tirana, the capital, is the country's beating cultural and industrial heart.

sections.title: Climate in Albania
content: The country enjoys a classic Mediterranean climate with mild, wet winters and hot, dry summers. Coastal regions stay pleasant year-round, while the Albanian Alps in the north offer a more rugged, mountainous environment.

sections.title: The Culture of Albania
content: Albanian culture is centered around family, hospitality, and a direct communication style. It is a society that places a high value on building strong personal relationships, which often serves as a prerequisite for successful business partnerships.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Albania
content: Albanian is the official language. Due to its historical ties and young, educated population, English and Italian are exceptionally common in business and professional circles, making it a highly accessible market for international teams.

sections.title: Personal Income Tax in Albania
content: Albania employs a progressive tax system. For 2026, personal income tax rates typically range from 13% to 23% depending on the salary level.

sections.title: Social Security in Albania
content: The social security system in Albania covers both social and health insurance. For 2026, the minimum salary threshold for contributions is set at ALL 50,000, while the maximum is ALL 186,416.

sections.title: Public Holidays Recognized by Albania in 2026
content: The Monday Rule: If an official public holiday falls on a weekend (Saturday or Sunday), the day off is usually observed on the following Monday.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries are typically paid monthly in Albanian Lek (ALL). While international contracts often benchmark salaries in EUR or USD, final payments must be executed in the national currency.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: The standard legal work week is 40 hours, usually structured as 8 hours per day over 5 days. Employers must maintain accurate records, as any work beyond these limits is treated as overtime, capped at an average of 48 hours per week.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees are entitled to a minimum of 4 calendar weeks (typically 20-22 working days) of paid annual leave per year. Some sectors provide up to 30 days depending on the contract.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 365 days of maternity leave. The first 6 months are compensated at 80% of the average net salary, while the remaining period is covered at 50%.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 3 days of paid paternity leave at the time of birth, covered by the employer.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: For an adopted child up to one year old, employees are entitled to 330 days of leave from the day of adoption.

countries.name: Kosovo
countries.title: Kosovo Country Guide
countries.description: Tapping into Europe's youngest workforce and a thriving digital ecosystem in the heart of the Balkans.

sections.title: Kosovo Introduction
content: Kosovo is one of Europe's newest and most dynamic nations. With a median age of around 30, it boasts the youngest population on the continent, characterized by high digital literacy and strong multilingual skills (English and German are widely spoken). Its strategic location and Euro-indexed economy make it an increasingly popular hub for IT outsourcing, customer support, and business services.

sections.title: What to Know about Kosovo's Geography
content: Landlocked in the center of the Balkans, Kosovo is surrounded by mountains and fertile plains. It shares borders with Albania, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and Serbia. The capital, Pristina, serves as the primary economic and cultural engine, while cities like Prizren and Peja are key secondary hubs for regional trade and services.

sections.title: Climate in Kosovo
content: Kosovo has a continental climate with four distinct seasons. Winters are cold and snowy, with temperatures often dropping below 0°C (32°F), while summers are warm and sunny, with averages around 26°C (79°F). The spring and autumn seasons are mild and ideal for travel and outdoor business activities.

sections.title: The Culture of Kosovo
content: Kosovan culture is known for its legendary hospitality and strong sense of community. It is a society that values entrepreneurship and is rapidly modernizing. In a business context, punctuality and direct communication are appreciated. Building a personal rapport is often a precursor to long-term professional partnerships.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Kosovo
content: Albanian and Serbian are the official languages. However, due to a large diaspora and a young, tech-savvy population, English is exceptionally common in professional settings. German is also frequently spoken, particularly in technical and engineering sectors, making Kosovo a highly versatile talent market.

sections.title: Personal Income Tax in Kosovo
content: Kosovo uses a progressive tax system that is very competitive compared to Western Europe. As of 2026, the rates are:
• 0% for income up to €3,000 annually.
• 8% for income between €3,001 and €5,400.
• 10% for income above €5,401.

sections.title: Social Security in Kosovo
content: The social security system is straightforward, focusing primarily on pension contributions. Unlike other regions, there is no separate mandated health insurance tax rate; social services are funded through the general budget and the pension system.

sections.title: Public Holidays Recognized by Kosovo in 2026
content: *Dates for religious holidays are subject to the lunar calendar.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries are paid monthly in Euro (EUR). Since the local economy is fully Euroized, there are no currency conversion risks for European clients paying into Kosovan bank accounts.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: The standard work week is 40 hours. Employers must maintain accurate records of daily hours, as any work beyond the 40-hour limit is classified as overtime and must be compensated accordingly.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees are entitled to a minimum of 4 weeks (20 working days) of paid leave per year. An additional day of leave is added for every five years of service with the same employer.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Total leave is 12 months. The first 6 months are paid by the employer at 70% of the salary. The following 3 months are covered by the government at 50% of the average national salary, and the final 3 months are unpaid.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 3 days of paid leave upon birth or adoption. They may also take an additional 2 weeks of unpaid leave at any time until the child turns three.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Employees who legally adopt a child under 1 year of age are entitled to the same leave benefits as biological parents, starting with 2 days paid and followed by the applicable parental leave periods to support family integration.

countries.name: North Macedonia
countries.title: North Macedonia Country Guide
countries.description: Unlocking growth in the heart of the Balkans with one of Europe's most competitive tax systems.

sections.title: North Macedonia Introduction
content: North Macedonia is a landlocked nation that has transformed into a strategic business hub. It offers one of the most attractive tax packages in Europe, specifically designed to stimulate international investment and simplify operations for successful global companies.

sections.title: What to Know about North Macedonia's Geography
content: Located in the northeastern part of the Balkan region, North Macedonia is characterized by its mountainous terrain and fertile valleys. It shares borders with Greece, Bulgaria, Serbia, Albania, and Kosovo, making it a central crossroads for trade in Southeastern Europe.

sections.title: Climate in North Macedonia
content: The country experiences a warm and moderately continental climate. It is characterized by a prolonged frost-free period and relatively mild winters, although snow cover is common in the mountainous regions during the winter months.

sections.title: The Culture of North Macedonia
content: Macedonian culture is a rich tapestry of Orthodox Christian and Muslim traditions, reflected in its architecture, festivals, and daily life. It is a society that deeply values family ties and hospitality. In business, building a foundation of mutual trust and maintaining professional etiquette are key to long-term success.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in North Macedonia
content: Macedonian is the primary official language, with Albanian also holding official status at the state level. English is widely spoken and understood, particularly within the professional, tech, and younger generations, facilitating smooth communication for international partners.

sections.title: Personal Income Tax in North Macedonia
content: North Macedonia utilizes a flat tax system for most types of income, making it highly transparent for employers.
• Flat Rate: 10% on almost all types of personal income.
• Exception: A 15% rate applies specifically to winnings from games of chance.

sections.title: Social Security in North Macedonia
content: The social security system covers pension, health, and unemployment insurance. Contributions are calculated based on the employee's gross wage.

sections.title: Public Holidays Recognized by North Macedonia in 2026

faqSection.sectionTitle: Important Information for North Macedonia Employees

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries are typically paid monthly in Macedonian Denar (MKD). Many international companies benchmark salaries in EUR or USD to attract top-tier talent, though final payment is executed in the local currency.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: The standard legal work week is 40 hours. Employers must maintain accurate records of daily working hours, as overtime is strictly regulated and requires additional compensation.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave, which can increase up to 26 days based on years of service with the same employer. Eligibility begins after 6 months of uninterrupted service.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 9 months of paid maternity leave (extended to 12 months for multiple births). This leave is typically funded by the State Fund for Health and Insurance.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 7 days of paid paternity leave following the birth of a child.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Employees who adopt a child are entitled to leave that can last up to 330 days after the child is born, ensuring support for family integration.

countries.name: Romania
countries.title: Romania Country Guide
countries.description: Accessing a premier EU tech hub with high-level linguistic diversity and a stable business framework.

sections.title: Romania Introduction
content: Romania is a prominent member of the European Union and one of the fastest-growing economies in the region. It has established itself as a global leader in IT outsourcing and business process services, offering a sophisticated workforce that combines technical excellence with deep cultural alignment with Western markets.

sections.title: What to Know about Romania's Geography
content: Located at the intersection of Central, Eastern, and Southeastern Europe, Romania features a diverse landscape dominated by the Carpathian Mountains and the Danube River. Its strategic position on the Black Sea provides essential maritime access and trade links to both Europe and Asia.

sections.title: Climate in Romania
content: The country experiences a temperate-continental climate with four distinct seasons. Winters can be cold and snowy, while summers are typically warm to hot, with coastal areas enjoying a pleasant sea breeze.

sections.title: The Culture of Romania
content: Romanian culture is a unique "Latin island" in a Slavic sea, blending Roman roots with Balkan and Central European influences. It is a society known for its resilience, creativity, and warm hospitality. In business, Romanians are professional and value clear structures, though they also place significant importance on building long-term, trust-based relationships.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Romania
content: Romanian is the official language. Due to high education standards and a history of foreign investment, English proficiency is exceptionally high among the workforce. French, German, and Italian are also widely spoken, making Romania one of the most linguistically versatile talent markets in Europe.

sections.title: Personal Income Tax in Romania
content: Romania applies a flat income tax rate of 10% on employment income. However, specific fiscal changes for 2026 have increased tax obligations for investment income and certain property-related taxes.

sections.title: Social Security in Romania
content: The social security system is largely funded by the employee, with a smaller contribution required from the employer.
Note: Employer pension contributions of 4% or 8% may apply for arduous or special working conditions.

sections.title: Public Holidays Recognized by Romania in 2026

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries are paid monthly in Romanian Leu (RON). While international firms often define salary packages in EUR, the actual payroll execution must occur in the local currency.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: The standard work week is 40 hours. Employers are legally required to keep accurate records of attendance and overtime, as Romanian Labor Law provides high levels of protection for workers regarding working time.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave. Those working in difficult or dangerous conditions are entitled to an additional 3 days of leave.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 126 calendar days (18 weeks) of maternity leave paid at 85% of their average monthly income. This is typically followed by a parental leave option of up to 2 years (or 3 years for children with disabilities).

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 5 to 10 working days of paid paternity leave, which can be extended to 15 days if the father attends a certified childcare training course.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: For legal adoptions, employees are entitled to leave that can last up to 330 days after the child is born to ensure proper family bonding and integration.
